narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The financial side of land management is critical, and this course provides a good background on financial analysis. The instructor was often unclear about what assignments were due when, and the lectures wavered from the syllabus somewhat. Still, the instructor was good, and passionate about his subject.The TA, Sarah Lowery, was exceptional. She worked very hard to help us understand the material, and was very clear with expectations.
4. The workload was not really hard conceptually, but it was alot in quantity. Almost too much and it wasn't very well spread out throughout the semester.

A very relevant course with important financial skills needed by every land manager. The examples and case studies was focused mainly on the United States rather than having an international feel. Too much problem set questions for this level of education making the process more mechanical rather than solving real life case studies. There is a lot of topics to be covered in a relatively short time.

(Regarding question 9a) The problem set assignments is the key element in this class. They are very useful but sometimes students have too many assignments in hand and the workload can be overwhelming. A little more organization is needed to ensure a better distribution of the assignments in the semester

The course is an essential for understanding how the forest industry works. It was well taught and through the many out of class assignments, forced me to struggle with the concepts to better understand them.
A very practical course with good case studies.
The homework forced me to really apply the concepts we learned. The mini project was also very useful in applying the concepts to a real life situation.

It was a great introduction to the basics of financial analysis. I think it was very simplified compared to what financial analysis would be like at SOM, but for non-SOM students with an interest in using financial tools, it was a great way to start building skills/knowledge in that area.
All the practice problem sets really helped me learn the material. I could see major progress in my understanding by the end of the semester.

The introduction to key investment appraisal tools like Net Present Value, Internal Rate of Return, etc. which are key in most financial analysis related to the management of natural resources.Another good thing about the course was the opportunity to undertake a mini-project in any area of interest and applying financial analysis tools to provide an evaluation of the situation and to offer recommendations.

-Lloyd presents useful material, with interesting insights as support.-Lloyd's passionate and very knowledgeable about the subject.-The miniproject was the most useful assignment (second was hogwarts)
forestry expertise of the professor
Professor Irland is very responsive and seems to enjoy teaching the course.

I am not a forester, so I learned a lot of new concepts in forestry. The course was a bit biased to plantations. I am now loaded with all the facts regarding establishment and management of plantations to maximize profit. This is cool as plantations can offer sustainable employment.
The Professor is extremely knowledgeable about the subject and he even offered extra sessions of interest to the students. I found those very useful
Lloyd's great attitude and teaching style.
The assignments.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The instructor needs to be more clear about when assignments are due, since he wavered from the syllabus.

The class should cover more concepts. I felt very frustrated by the fact that the only theories and concepts we learned were presented in the first third of the course. The rest of the course was application of those concepts, but I felt that we could have covered more material.

Lloyd needs to communicate better with students his expectations, the schedule the class, assignments, etc. I found myself spending half my time on assignments just trying to decipher what he was asking us to do. The work for the class could also be more evenly dispersed rather then coming in spurts with multiple things do at once and then a week or two of nothing due.

I would have liked to see more non-timber land management applications since my interest is not in timber management. I know Lloyd is a timber guy, so perhaps it's an opportunity for some guest speakers?

-a few of the homework assignments should have been cut. We reached a point int he semester where we had too much due on consecutive class periods. This left little time to thoroughly read the assigned material.
may consider moving the pace up a little
The instructor needs to be more organized and prepared before the class.

1) A better assignment distribution2) A better in-class analysis of the assignments. THe assignments by themselves are of great help but i think that more emphasis should be placed on explaining the details of the assignments and their relation to the lectures and their overall importance

There were just too many assignments and they were not spread out well. Sometimes we would go two weeks without an assignment and then we would have one due every class for two weeks.Also, limiting assignments will allow students to spend more time on individual ones and grasp concepts better. Often I was so rushed that I wasn't able to conceptualize the assignment and simply messed around with the equation until i got it right.

Making the lectures relevant. I learned the most from this class while wrestling with the assignments, the lectures were interesting but didn't register as much as the assignments did. The lectures gave context to the numbers used in the assignments but didn't deepen my understanding of the material.
The professor fell behind in the syllabus and I feel like we didn't cover as much ground as we could have. I would have liked more emphasis on topics other than forests.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both were very approachable and helpful.
Lloyd is very accessible, helpful and easy to talk to. Sarah was a great TA. Very responsive and helpful.

Lloyd was always willing to sit down with us, or answer e-mails, but I think most of the students used the TA, Sarah. She was great and more than willing to hold long office hours to help us figure out the concepts and assignments.

Sarah (TA) was AWESOME! I wouldn't have made it through without her weekly TA sessions. She often stayed over the alloted session hours to help those who still had questions. She maintained frequent communication with the class. Super helpful!
Both lecturer and TA were readily available beyond lecture periods and I consulted the lecturer on a few occasions.
Significant amount of time. High quality.
very good
The TA put in a lot of time grading, holding office hours and answering our questions. I thought she did an excellent job.
The instructor tried to make himself available but he needs to improve on this. The TA was available and very helpful.
She's a bit rough on the edges as a TA but approachableBoth the professor and the TA were always helpful when needed
Both Lloyd and Sarah were readily available and more than willing to help out when concepts or assignments proved difficult.
The TA was exceptional, was available for help when needed and took on an incredible amount of work to make this class as successful as it was.
Excellent availability by both the TA and instructor

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Financial constraints are very important in the overall study of land management, and so this course was very valuable.
This course provided me with some beginnings of finance that I had never learned before. It also was very applicable to forestry, which is my focus.

I think learning how land management decisions are affected by financial considerations is key, so for me it was an essential skill to acquire at FESfor my future career in land management and conservation.

I think the ability to make financial judgements is helpful in any environmental profession. My interest is in land conservation for water quality protection, and I feel comfortable that I now have a basic ability to allocate resources based on financial analysis.
Very well. I had some prior investment appraisal experience and this course has deepened my understanding and scope of applications these powerful tools can be put to.
Fits extremely well. Perhaps Lloyd should consider splitting this into two classes. One for MFs to take their first year, one the next. I think others would agree with this.

As someone trying to specialize in environmental/resource economics, this course was very useful. I learned and practiced the use of different financial metrics and how to allocate land to the most profitable use(s).

Every forester needs to know about financial matters. this class is very important in this sense, especially for MF students but also for Science degrees students that wish to have a better understanding of real-life financial decisions
As stated above, this course is fundamental to understanding how the forest industry works.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: For a background in financial considerations of land management.
To get a better understanding of how forest valuation and the forest industry works. I also liked the things I heard about Lloyd.
I heard it was challenging but informative and a good introduction to financial analysis for non-business school students.

I wanted some experience with financial analysis, having worked for a non-profit for three years that was greatly hindered by financial woes. I also wanted to learn a practical tool to apply to myfuture career.
I wanted to strengthen my financial analysis skills
interested in forestry finance
I was interest in the financial side of land management, as I'm interested in land and wildlife management in general.

I needed a course which is a direct application of economics. This and agriculture and environment were the two course that employed economic concepts to address environmental challenges. But I opted for this one due conflicting schedule.
Because of what I explained in question 15
It is the only class offered that covers the financial concepts and decision-making processes for resource management at the ground level.
I think it is a requirement, if it is not, it should be.
Reputation of the instructor

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes. The material provided is very practical and useful

It did in some respects, in that Lloyd provided very useful and real-world insights about forestry. However, I still feel that we didn't cover enough concepts. I still feel like a beginner in finance.
Yes. I learned alot, was challenged, and feel like I walk away with a foundation in financial analysis and an interest in learning more sophisticated and complicated analysis tools.
Yes!
In some respects yes.
yes!!
yes
Yes.
Yes. Most of the materials were new to me.
Even more so. It was plenty of work but very good at teaching the student basic financial tools and making the student familiar to financial language
Yes
And then some, a lot of work and a lot of learning for me.
Absolutely

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes.
I was hoping to learn more about finance and less about topics like rangeland management.
Yes.
I did learn a practical tool, however, I would have appreciated a greater emphasis on non-timber land management applications.
To some extent.
Yes!
yes
Yes. But I feel like I expected more. Land management is not only about forests. I would like it more if they covered wildlife too.
Yes
Yes
More.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Didn't work with a group, other than students who were at TA sessions at the same time.
N/A
ALthough, unofficially, we would get together in groups to work on the problem sets which is very useful when tackling financial problems. group work should be encouraged in this class

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Work to understand the Why of the assignments, not just how to fill out the spreadsheets.
The readings, lectures and homeworks are not very related. Interact with Lloyd outside of class to get the most out of the class.

Its a good course. Stay on top of the homework. Do the reading because it is actually a good textbook. And talk with Lloyd, make sure you get him to tell you what is coming up, what you are responsible for, what he is asking for on assignments, etc. so you don't have to play guess with him throughout the semester.
Do the homework.
Sharpen your quantitative skills and come to class prepared (read around the topic and be ready to ask questions and share your views and experience on issues).
I hope you like problem sets.
Yes. If you are interested in managing land for profit, then this is the class for you.

It's a lot of work.Be prepared to dedicated much time to it, but you will learn a bunch about financial matters and also to understanding (at a simple level) financial jargon. very useful for professionals that work with landowners since you learn to speak their language -the financial language-.

The Mini-Project is not Mini, it is a full scale final project; act accordingly. There is a lot of work associated with this course, do it all and try not to get behind. This class will take a lot of your time, make sure you have it.
